message.content:
**1) Analyzing the Main Target Image**

- **Overall Count and Layers**

  There are **two separate “mini‐structures”** (left and right), each made up of **eight blocks**, for a total of **16 blocks**:

  • **Left Gateway (8 pieces)**  
    – Two tall green pillars on either side  
    – Two upright orange cylinders in the middle  
    – One red arch spanning the cylinders  
    – Two small orange wedges at the base (one by each green pillar)  
    – One orange wedge perched on top of the red arch  

  • **Right Temple (8 pieces)**  
    – A base of three red blocks (two arches on the ends, one “arch‐turned‐sideways” in the center)  
    – A yellow rectangular beam bridging across these red base blocks  
    – Two tall green pillars standing on that beam  
    – Another yellow beam across the tops of the green pillars  
    – One orange wedge on the very top  

- **Spatial/Layer Breakdown**

  • **Left Structure Layers**  
    – **Bottom Layer:** Green pillars and orange wedges on the outside, orange cylinders in the middle.  
    – **Middle Layer:** A red arch block that rests on the two orange cylinders.  
    – **Top Layer:** A single orange wedge sits atop the arch.  

  • **Right Structure Layers**  
    – **Layer 1 (Base):** Three red blocks in a row (the two outer ones show the arch opening from the front; the center one has its arch turned sideways so it looks rectangular from the front).  
    – **Layer 2:** One long yellow rectangular beam spans across those three red blocks.  
    – **Layer 3:** Two tall green pillars stand on that yellow beam.  
    – **Layer 4:** Another long yellow beam atop the green pillars.  
    – **Layer 5 (Top):** A single orange wedge forms the “roof.”  

---

**2) Selecting the Required Blocks from the Dictionary**

Below is the exact match of each block (by dictionary index), including the needed multiples:

• **Red Arch Blocks**  
  – #1 used three times (front‐facing arch shape).  
  – #2 used once (arch turned sideways so it appears rectangular from the front).  

• **Green Vertical Pillars**  
  – #5 used four times (all tall, upright green rectangles).  

• **Yellow Horizontal Beams**  
  – #7 used twice (the flat yellow rectangular prisms placed horizontally).  

• **Orange Cylinders (Upright)**  
  – #10 used twice (the vertical orange cylinders on the left gateway).  

• **Orange Wedges**  
  – #12 used two times (the small wedges at the base of the left gateway).  
  – #13 used two times (the “roof” wedges on top of each structure).  

No other dictionary blocks are needed.

---

**3) Step‐by‐Step Assembly Order**

Below is one possible build sequence (you may group or reorder the steps so long as lower layers go first).  

{
  Step1: Move block with index 5       // Left gateway, first green pillar  
  Step2: Move block with index 12      // Left gateway, orange wedge at base  
  Step3: Move block with index 10      // Left gateway, first upright cylinder  
  Step4: Move block with index 10      // Left gateway, second upright cylinder  
  Step5: Move block with index 5       // Left gateway, second green pillar  
  Step6: Move block with index 12      // Left gateway, second orange wedge at base  
  Step7: Move block with index 1       // Left gateway, red arch over cylinders  
  Step8: Move block with index 13      // Left gateway, orange wedge roof  

  Step9:  Move block with index 1      // Right temple, left red arch  
  Step10: Move block with index 2      // Right temple, center red “sideways” arch  
  Step11: Move block with index 1      // Right temple, right red arch  
  Step12: Move block with index 7      // Right temple, first yellow beam  
  Step13: Move block with index 5      // Right temple, left green column  
  Step14: Move block with index 5      // Right temple, right green column  
  Step15: Move block with index 7      // Right temple, second yellow beam  
  Step16: Move block with index 13     // Right temple, orange wedge roof
}

Following the above list of blocks (with the exact orientations shown in the dictionary) will recreate the target image precisely.
